captions.text: Humans are masters of self-deception.

We fool ourselves into
believing things that are false

and we refuse to
believe things that are true.
I was in graduate school

when I really started
delving into the topic of self-deception.
And it rocked my world.
I saw it everywhere,
in everyone.

We lie to ourselves
about the smallest details,
such as how much we really ate today,

and why we didn't list
our actual height and weight
on our driver's license.
(Laughter)
We lie to reflect our aspirational goals:

"I'll only have
one glass of wine tonight," --

when I know I'm drinking 
at least three. (Laughter)
We lie to uphold social ideals:

"I never have sexual thoughts
with anyone except my spouse,"
because that wouldn't be acceptable.

We lie about
our most important life choices,

such as why we married who we did,
or chose our given career path.

Unfortunately,
for all the romantics out there,

love is rarely the full motivation 
for those choices.

Nowhere was self-deception more obvious
than in my romantic relationships.
I was terrified of being left.

My fear of abandonment 
led me to act in ways
that are still hard for me to admit --
anxiously awaiting a phone call,

driving to see if he was
where he said he would be,
asking repeatedly if he loved me.

At the time,
I couldn't have told you any of that,

because I wouldn't have been able to
admit it to myself.
At the core, we lie to ourselves

because we don't have enough
psychological strength to admit the truth

and deal with the consequences
that will follow.
That said, understanding our self-deception

is the most effective way
to live a fulfilling life.
For when we admit who we really are,
we have the opportunity to change.
It's hard to look at this photo and think,
"Liars!"
(Laughter)

But our self-deceptive tendencies
start here.

From a very early age
we start observing

and making conclusions about ourselves
and our environment.

Right or wrong, the conclusions we made
affected our identity.
As adults, we will most want to lie about

how psychologically painful realities
experienced as children
affected who we are today.

Perhaps you were raised
in a single parent home,

in which you were neglected
by your father.

You learned that 
something was wrong with you --

you weren't smart enough,
attractive enough, athletic enough.

You concluded that
to make people love you,
you need to be perfect.
As an adult,

when someone
points out your imperfections,

you feel tremendous anxiety
but deny where it comes from.

Perhaps you felt ugly as a child because 
you were teased for your appearance.

You learned to eat
in response to emotional pain.

As an adult, you struggle to
maintain a stable weight,

because your eating
has very little to do with hunger.
Perhaps you watched your parents fight.
You learned to avoid conflict.

Now, you struggle to admit even
feeling negative emotion.

Although each of our specific 
childhood learnings will be unique,

what we learned will be exemplified
in the lies we tell ourselves as adults.

Psychological theories of human nature
can help us understand our self-deception.

Sigmund Freud first described lying
through ego-defense mechanisms:

Psychological strategies
that protect our egos
-- our core sense of self --
from information that would hurt us.
Denial:

Refusing to believe
that something is true,
even though it is.
"I don't have a problem with alcohol," --
even though I drink everyday.
"I'm not jealous," --

even though I secretly check
my partner's email.
Rationalization:
Creating a reason to excuse ourselves.

"I wouldn't have yelled at you
if you hadn't treated me so unfairly,"
thereby justifying my yelling.

"I know that smoking
isn't good for my health,
but it helps me relax,"
thereby justifying my smoking.
Projection:

Taking an undesirable aspect of ourselves
and ascribing it to someone else.
"I'm not like that. You're like that."

When dating someone
you've lost interest in,
you say things like,
"You're not ready for this relationship,"

when, in fact,
you're not ready for this relationship
and never will be!

Pioneers in the 
cognitive-behavioral realms
describe how our thoughts deceive us

through cognitive distortions --
irrational ways we think.

Polarized Thinking:
Thinking in extremes.

“I will either eat no cookies
or an entire box,
because if I eat one cookie,

I've already blown my diet, 
so I might as well keep eating.”
Emotional Reasoning:

Thinking that our feelings
accurately reflect reality.

“I feel hurt; so you must have
done something bad to me.”

“I feel stupid;
consequently I am stupid.”
Overgeneralization:

Taking a single negative event
as an infinite spiral of defeat.

After going through a bad breakup,
you think,
“I am always going to be alone.”

After getting denied a promotion
at work, you think,

“I am never going to be successful
in my career.”
From an existential perspective,

we deceive ourselves
to avoid the Givens of Life --

the fundamental realities of
"being human" that we must face.
Death – we’re all going to die;
Ultimate aloneness --

we were born as a single person housed
in a solitary physical body;
Meaninglessness --

our lives are inherently meaningless
unless we give them meaning;
and Freedom --

we are responsible for ourselves
because we have the freedom of choice.

To avoid confronting these realities,
we frequently lie to ourselves:

“I am this way
because of my upbringing;” --

thereby deferring responsibility
for my choices.

“The bad things on the news
would never happen to me;” --

because I am somehow special, 
and uniquely protected from harm.

“I won’t write a will. I am young.
I’m not going to die anyway;” --
thereby denying our mortality.
Multicultural and feminist psychologists

describe how internalization
of cultural norms affect us.
Here, we deceive ourselves by believing

what we were culturally conditioned
to believe is true,

instead of deciding
what we actually believe is true.

Do you compromise yourself
to meet cultural norms?

Do you think you need 
to look a certain way,
be a certain weight,
earn a certain income,
get married, have children, be religious
because you are supposed to

or because you believe
that it's right for you?

All of these theories of human nature
help us understand
how we deceive ourselves on a daily basis.
Why should you care?

Self-deception leads to
massive amounts of pain and regret.
To avoid being honest,

we frequently make choices
with harmful consequences
to ourselves and others --

we may use drugs, alcohol, eat,
shop, gamble, steal, lie, leave people

or pass our emotional baggage down
to those we love the most.
Or, we may choose not to change
even when we are miserable
or causing profound harm to those around us.

Looking back at life with regret
is incredibly painful,

because you can’t change 
your choices in the past.
As I shared earlier,

I struggled greatly
in my romantic relationships.
I knew that I didn't feel safe,

but I believed
it was my boyfriend’s fault --

if he just called me more,
told me he loved me more,
then I would feel safe.
The truth was

there was nothing he could do
to make me feel safe,

because my feelings
had nothing to do with him.

The reason I didn't feel safe
is that I learned as a child
that people would always leave me,

and I lived my life making choices
consistent with that belief.

When we don't take full responsibility
for who we are,

we hurt ourselves
and everyone around us.
Now what?

How do we start acknowledging the lies
we tell ourselves?

How do we start
becoming more honest liars?
The first step is self-awareness --
we become observers of ourselves.

When you have a strong emotional reaction
to something,
pause.

When what you say
doesn't match how you act,
pause.
When you’re thinking irrational thoughts,
pause.
Ask yourself:
What does this say about me?

Similarly, most of us spend
a tremendous amount of energy

trying to get over someone or something
that happened to us.

And we generally avoid examining
our contribution to conflict in our lives.

When you are unresolved
about something or someone,
pause.
Ask yourself:

What does my reaction to this situation
say about me?
As we become more honest and aware,

we also become more responsible
for our choices.

If we admit that
we are insecure about something
-- which we all are --
we're now confronted with a choice:
to work on our insecurity or not.
Whatever we decide,

we are now more responsible
for the consequences of our insecurity,
because we know better.

Not changing when confronted
with the truth is a choice.

Although we can’t control
many circumstances we encounter in life,

we are responsible
for our reactions to all of them.
In that vein, one of the best ways
to confront our self-deception
is psychotherapy.
It is probably the only relationship

that you will ever have
in your entire life
that exists solely to benefit you.

Yet, a great deal of stigma
exists around therapy.
People frequently say things like,
“I don't need therapy.

It’s only for crazy or weak people
who can't help themselves.”
The truth is, it takes tremendous courage

to be completely vulnerable
to another human being.

Therapy is truly a gift if
you are courageous enough to accept it.

Confronting our self-deception
is a lifelong journey.

We change and the world offers us
new opportunities
to understand ourselves.
There is always more to learn.

I was on the perfect path
to be a successful academic.

I received tenure
here at UNLV, two years ago.

And in about six weeks,
I will be unemployed,
because I resigned.
Getting tenure and then quitting

is about the last thing anyone 
would expect from a faculty member.
Especially me. I love psychology!

I love teaching. I love research. 
I love my department.
I had an amazing experience at UNLV.

But the truth is,
my passion isn't in academia anymore.

To admit that to myself
was brutally painful!

Because I had to confront all of my
self-deceptive tendencies and insecurities.
"What if I disappoint people?
What will my family say?

What am I gonna do? 
What if I can’t support myself?
Who am I if I am not a professor?
What if my whole life changes!?
What if my whole life doesn't change?"
If I had chosen to stay in academia,

I would have paid 
a huge psychological price.

I would have to admit
that I was not strong enough

to make different choices for myself
when confronted with the truth.
Be more honest liars.

Choose to become more honest
about the lies you tell yourself.

Use the truth to live
the most fulfilling life for you,
because you only got one.
(Applause)

title: Honest liars -- the psychology of self-deception: Cortney Warren at TEDxUNLV

comments.text:
Why we lie to ourselves, False Emotions/Experiences Appearing Real..... If 
we lie to ourselves for to hide ourselves it is to shield ourselves from 
our FEAR of our own potential . ﻿

comments.text:
If you'd like to use her inaccurate terminology, she is lying from the 
first to the last moment of this vid. Look at her body language and facial 
expression. It is manipulation. She is in effect saying, 'please like me, 
please agree with me, I'm cool, beautiful and right.' She is doing all of 
this each moment on stage. Is this lying, deception? It is in fact 
manipulation but it is so ingrained in normal social behavior that we don't 
usually question the unconscious 'lying' going on almost every moment of 
most communication.﻿
comments.author: brazfan

comments.text:
She is trying to say something true but she is lying to make her point. No 
one willingly, knowingly deceives themselves. She's making it sound like 
people do this on purpose but they do not. This is called blame the victim. 
It is equivalent of blaming a child for not having a PHD. People are 
hurting due to old traumas, most of which they cannot remember because they 
happened very early, attachment bonds betrayed in earliest life. She is in 
fact a dangerous narcissist who probably betrayed her own child.﻿

comments.text:
To all, I obviously let my emotion get the best of me. But I acknowledge 
the benefits of psychology & therapy. To all who are studying in this 
field, I wish you success & may you reach your professional goals. I knew 
my marriage was in trouble in 2003 & I CHOSE to stick it out after years & 
years of disappointments. So, I can't criticize or let self-negativity 
attempt to discredit professionals in this field. I thank Google Plus for 
the positive messages & thank the various ppl who w/ a few genuine words 
gave me strength to continue. Thank you again. Regards, Tina

comments.text:
I love her inclusion of existential truths. Acknowledging and integrating 
these truths into our lives is very painful yet absolutely necessary to 
becoming better human beings. No great person has ever lived who did not 
realize their own mortality, loneliness and the meaninglessness of the 
world. Realizing these truths leads to the last realization: freedom. 
Accepting without compromise the truth of our existence gives us absolute, 
radical freedom to live the lives we've always dreamed of. And the 
responsibility to be better.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: brazfan

comments.text:
+Josée What is so dangerous about this talk is that, in general everyone 
can relate to her.

Everyone lies some times, even if it is just little white lies, so you 
don't hurt anyone.

However, the extend of lying she is talking about, and the situations she 
talks about points to a narcissistic and therefore very abusive personality 
type.

....You can stop here, if you don't want to know the details....
-----
There are many other aspects and methods that the narcissist employs and 
combined they are very destructive to there partner.

The narcissist is someone who is insecure and self centred to  the point 
where he or she won't admit any fault, twists the facts so the other person 
is always to blame, manipulates situations to such an extend that their 
partner starts questioning their own sanity.

We may all do some of what she says, but not all of it.

What it leads to is mental anguish, isolation, financial loss (possibly 
their entire life savings, as in my case) to there partner.  Add on top of 
that, that they will lie and twist the truth to blame the other person 
(their partner was abusive, stole from them, never did any work around the 
house, lied and manipulated them, ruining the other persons reputation and 
alienating him from friends and family) when in actuality it is just a 
projection of what the narcissistic person has done to the partner, 
sometimes for years (as in my case) or decades!

Their partner is usually co-dependent, (as I am), meaning they are overly 
honest, trusting and kind.  That is why I can't relate at all to what she 
is saying and why I am so offended by this presentation.  It is a pack of 
lies that makes her out to be some sort of hero, facing adversity and 
overcoming her weaknesses, when it is nothing of the kind.

There is a great deal of psychological abuse that this type of person piles 
upon their victims.

Lying is only one aspect of what they do, so admitting you lie doesn't 
begin to cover the extent of the ailment.  That is why I question her 
motives.

She hasn't admitted how badly she has abused her partner, the other tactics 
she uses (shaming, guilting, twisting the truth, omitting the truth, 
stealing), how she uses and discards people, her over inflated ego and 
sense of entitlement or the fact that they show no empathy for others, are 
very materialistic and hasn't shown an ounce of shame, guilty or remorse.

She has made up a category "psychology of self-deception" instead of 
calling it narcissistic or the proper names for what she does.  As a Dr of 
psychology she should have easily been able to name the conditions 
involved. (There are 10 psychological conditions, many of which relate to 
this condition).

That is why I question her sincerity and suspect she is hiding the truth, 
even while she's pretending to tell the truth!

They are that twisted!
-----
This presentation should never have been put on TED talks.

It seems to present a good message, (because most people don't understand 
the context or the psychological ramifications), but the speaker is just 
stroking her own ego.
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text:
Okay, well seeing as I don't even do relationships myself (I'm 25 and I've 
been in a few short ones) I was mostly talking about things outside of just 
relationships. I mean in every day life, in how you view yourself in the 
world, in how you think of what's valuable in the world, etc. etc. It's my 
belief that pretty much everybody lies to themselves on an every day basis, 
but that doesn't mean we are not to trust ourselves.I'll leave it at that 
though I don't want to rub you the wrong way or anything. I just took her 
message in the broader sense, idk it's been a while since I watched it as 
well.
comments.author: Josée

comments.text:
+Josée It's not the delivery.

She is narcissistic. It was creepy and twisted.

I know, I've been through narcissistic abuse.

-----

Most people don't deceive themselves the way she is describing, twisting 
relationships etc.

Most people don't have deep rooted psychological issues based not getting 
attention when they were a child.


Most people don't twist relationships to their favour and lie to get their 
way to the extent of a narcissist.

Most people don't twist the facts to make themselves sound like some sort 
of hero overcoming adversity.


Most people don't tell others they are wrong and how to change their lives.

Even the title, she started out by projecting her shame onto everyone else 
"Everyone lies".

-----


And no, I don't feel better afterwards.


Firstly I don't lie to myself or deceive others. I'm a co-dependent 
personality type, meaning honest, giving and trusting. The very personality 
type that narcissists take advantage of and abuse!
comments.author: 123abcbruce

comments.text:
There is a huge element of truth to what she says.  
Example-  My job is being outsourced and I have been reassigned to a much 
easier job at the same pay.  I was physically sick over this until I 
figured out exactly what about it was stressing me out the most.  Was it 
fear I wasn't worthy of a better job?  Or that management didn't value me? 
 Would I be able to rearrange my life around a less predictable schedule? 
 NO.  I was afraid I would lose part of my identity.    It took me about 7 
pages of journaling to understand that about myself...  
So I get the point of the speech.  It's crazy how easy it is to draw the 
wrong conclusions about yourself and others.   A lot of people don't get it 
because it's hard to look at yourself objectively (or compassionately).﻿
comments.author: Candidly Poppy

comments.text:
*Above all, do not lie to yourself. A man who lies to himself and listens 
to his own lie comes to a point where he does not discern any truth either 
in himself or anywhere around him, and thus falls into disrespect towards 
himself and others.*
-Fyodor Dostoyevsky
Be true to yourself. Start by reading ∂The Present∂ at *The Truth Contest*

comments.text:
It's not that she was bad.  Her "performance" was very good.  (Indeed her 
performance was flawless.)

However, the content along with her presentation wasn't rational.

It sounds good, in principle, but when you put it in context with reality, 
a normally person would not say it or present it that way.

There was a lot of self projection in what she was saying.

... Fear of abandonment...dishonest intentions for marriage, definite signs 
of narcissism.

It wasn't just a case of improper acting.

It was very creepy.
------
I am literally saying I see signs of narcissism.  There's an arrogance and 
an "I know better than you" attitude.

 A normal person would not assume that everybody lies.

A normal person would never run into the topic of self-deception and be 
"Blown away".

A normal person would never call herself an "Honest Liar". 

That's self deception on the topic of self deception.

It's very narcissistic.
-----
Narcissism is caused by lack of affection from the parents.  Hence 
insecurity and fears of abandonment.  In that she is right.

There are a lot of other symptoms and reasons and she actually listed a lot 
of actions that narcissists do in a relationship, but the fact is she is a 
narcissist projecting her issues onto the audience.  It's self 
justification.

It's just not true, normal people don't act or do what she says "we all do".
------
The good thing is that she is admitting she has a problem, even if it's in 
a round about way.

I don't know if she knows she is a narcissist, most narcissists can't admit 
they have a problem or take responsibility for there own actions.

The phrase "Honest Liar" seems side step admitting her true condition.

Indeed "The psychology of self-deception" isn't a condition and she avoided 
any proper psychological terms, which would have easily pointed to her 
condition, .

I don't know that she has truly admitted anything to herself, it was mostly 
directed at the audience and grandstanding to make herself look like a hero.

comments.text:
+Cabaliero You know, now that you mention it, her ear lobes....------
Sorry, I'm judging but I think there's a big difference between selfish 
people and honest people.
-----
Someone selfish would say that everyone lies, then go on to tell others 
what they should do.

Someone honest wouldn't impose their ideas on others or assume that 
everyone lies.
-----
The former sounds a bit sociopathic and instead of taking responsibility 
for there lying claims that everyone lies and then proceeds to tell 
everyone that they all lie, to justify their lying and deflect the 
responsibility from themselves.
-----
What she is saying just sounds odd.

Someone who deceives themselves would not admit to it. It's not their 
fault, it's everyone elses.

Something just doesn't ring true.
------
There are different personality types.
- Selfish people lie to get what they want and deflect guilt.
- Nurturers take responsibility for their actions and often take on too 
much responsibility for others as well.

The type of person who would assume that everyone lies or claim to be an 
"Honest liar" sounds to me like a pathological liar or worse a 
sociopath/narcissist.
-----
I may be wrong, she may just be overacting, but something just doesn't 
sound sincere with her presentation.

comments.text:
The moment she mentioned academic Feminism I just switched off. Sorry, but 
there's nothing rational about Feminism - even at an academic level, it's 
all just emotionalist garbage, a pack of ideologues unwilling to even 
consider that their personal world view may in fact be flawed.

I do appreciate her individualist ideas though, but frankly there are 
aspects not only of human nature but also our own nature that are flawed 
and the best we can do is acknowledge them - there is no real way to fix 
them. So the cycle of 'self-deception' must be maintainted unless you wish 
to let your shadow take control and likely end up in a mental institution.

Think of the most extreme example of violent human behaviour - we all have 
the potential to behave in such a manner within us. Should we really let it 
out? I think not.﻿

comments.text:
+Andrew Hammond Okay I'll just add that it's pretty clear that the only 
person lying to themselves here is you. Seriously dude, re-read your 
comment and then try to find the point where I actually said ANYTHING 
you've been rambling on about.

Your entire argument is based upon assumptions you've made, you've lied to 
yourself so that you can actually justify your bullshit opinion. Meanwhile, 
all I've done is point out that ACADEMIC Feminism is toxic - which it is. 
Seriously dude, you obviously don't know shit about this so stop trying to 
talk about things you know nothing about.

Me and many other people have experienced the toxicity of academic 
Feminism. Just continue pretending that it doesn't exist, keep lying to 
yourself, it's cool bro - you're only human.
comments.author: TDMFAN

comments.text:
+Andrew Hammond For a minute there I thought you were *special* and might 
produce a well-reasoned argument, but instead it's just the same old 
garbage.

'Feminism is the social and economic equality of both genders.'

No, it isn't. Feminism is a movement and an ideology. Two different things, 
indeed connected to one another, but separate none-the-less.

'To be clear, you're saying that there is nothing logical about a women 
getting paid the same amount as a man, solely because she's a women. In 
fact, you take this a step further by saying that "feminists have a flawed 
view of the world," with no facts or backup of any sort to support your 
claim. I would love to hear how equality is considered "flawed logic."'

So many straw men, so many red herrings. You want some evidence to backup 
my claim - you're providing it just by responding.

'I bet, if the demographics you fit into came experienced discrimination or 
lower pay, you'd start to care a whole lot, wouldn't you?'

Red herring/ad hominem hybrid? Definitely trying to attack me personally 
for no real reason at all besides having an opinion about a 
movement/ideology.

'It's this twisted mindset you have that led to the Halocaust, and 
countless forms of oppression around the world.'

I don't know what the Halocaust is, but it was an ideology of victimhood 
similar to modern Feminism that lead to the Holocaust. You see, German 
people were suffering - as women have been for quite some time. The Nazis 
came along and blamed the Jews, who were better off at the time than the 
German people, for the German peoples' suffering. In a similar way, 
Feminism blames men (or some metaphor for men such as 'Patriarchy') and 
thus they justify treating men like shit with 'well now you're getting a 
taste of your own medicine' or 'you're just losing privileges, deal with 
it'... pretty much how the Nazis would have viewed their oppression of the 
Jews as being justified.

'You reject equality of others because - in comparison - you'd no longer be 
"superior"; and you need every and any form of mental reassurance so you 
can find to avoid the fact that you're not better than anyone. The mental 
gymnastics you must have gone through to make yourself believe that you are 
"better" than others just because of the way you were born is appalling.'

More ad hominems, red herrings... just irrelevant fictional bullshit that 
you're creating in order to set up the scene, to create a fictional enemy 
for you to attack.

...and with that I'm not even going to bother addressing the rest of your 
comment because you clearly have nothing relevant to say at all.
comments.author: TDMFAN

comments.text:
"There's nothing rational about feminism."

 Haha... for a minute there I thought your comment was a joke, being filled 
with hypocrisies and contradictions. But, then I realized you were actually 
this... "special."

Feminism is the social and economic equality of both genders. To be clear, 
you're saying that there is nothing logical about a women getting paid the 
same amount as a man, solely because she's a women. In fact, you take this 
a step further by saying that "feminists have a flawed view of the world," 
with no facts or backup of any sort to support your claim. I would love to 
hear how equality is considered "flawed logic."

I bet, if the demographics you fit into came experienced discrimination or 
lower pay, you'd start to care a whole lot, wouldn't you?

It's this twisted mindset you have that led to the Halocaust, and countless 
forms of oppression around the world. You reject equality of others because 
- in comparison - you'd no longer be "superior"; and you need every and any 
form of mental reassurance so you can find to avoid the fact that you're 
not better than anyone. The mental gymnastics you must have gone through to 
make yourself believe that you are "better" than others just because of the 
way you were born is appalling.

Had you focused on the video, and not the fact that the presenter was a 
women, perhaps you'd understand that it's your chronic stupidity and false 
logic that is being addressed. Perhaps you'd also realize that 
self-deception does not prevent humans as a species from committing random 
acts of violence because "it's in our nature." Notice that I said stupidity 
and not ignorance because you have been confronted with new information 
that disproves your "logic," but still make the decision to believe that 
you are 100% correct.

 Like Ms. Warren stated in the video, you need to accept the fact that you 
are wrong, or you'll never be able to change. I honestly don't know why I'm 
wasting my time trying to help you; you'll do whatever it takes to convince 
yourself that you're right, even if it means changing the perception of 
your own words.

By addressing the lies that you tell yourself to avoid change, you can 
better understand the causes and consequences of maintaing a specific 
behavior. I don't know what you were smoking, or what you were watching, 
but it clearly wasn't this video.

I would recommend seeing a doctor of some sort; you must have something 
wrong with your head.
